p: All Sesamum species studied so far produce lignans. Sesamin and sesamolin were detected in most species and we assume that all Sesamum species produce these two lignans, though most species accumulate them in lower levels than S. indicum. In addition to sesamin and sesamolin, some sesame species produce unique lignans not occurring in S. indicum ( Table 2). These species are of commercial interest as a source of enzymes and genes for the engineering of lignan biosynthesis (K. Dossa, personal communication).
